conversation.content: Hello doctor, I have abdominal pain and bloating, and I keep vomiting repeatedly.
Hello. How long have these symptoms been going on?
About a week. It started after I got drunk on the evening of the first day of the Lunar New Year, and it’s been four days now. The symptoms have been getting worse.
Can you tell me more specifically which part of your abdomen hurts?

Upper abdominal distending pain, a persistent dull ache that was tolerable at first, but then it became more and more painful. Now it’s continuous and radiates to my lower back, wrapping around like a belt.
Do you have any underlying medical conditions?
Do you have any family history of cancer?
What tests have you undergone so far?
Physical examination, blood tests, abdominal ultrasound, gastroscopy, serum and urine amylase tests, and an abdominal CT scan.
Could you provide the results of these tests?

Physical examination: temperature 38.5°C, pulse 120 bpm, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, blood pressure 149/110 mmHg; generalized jaundice of the skin and mucosa; abdominal distension; tenderness in the upper abdomen; decreased bowel sounds.

Blood test results: TBIL 123.1 μmol/L, DBIL 99.0 μmol/L, ALT 609 U/L, AST 308 U/L, ALP 245 U/L, GGT 1057 U/L, WBC 16.49 ×10⁹/L, Neut% 89.1%, Glucose 13.86 mmol/L, Triglycerides 6.25 mmol/L.

Ultrasound: gallstones, cholecystitis, dilated common bile duct.

Gastroscopy: chronic superficial gastritis with erosions.

Serum amylase (AMY) 2642 IU/L, urine amylase (UAMY) 2315 IU/L.

Abdominal CT: necrotizing pancreatitis, gallstones, bilateral pleural effusion.
Have the tumor marker test results come back?
No tumor marker tests were performed.

Diagnosis:
1. Conclusion: Necrotizing pancreatitis
   Reasoning: Blood tests show alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 245 U/L, γ-glutamyl transferase (GGT) 1057 U/L, white blood cell count (WBC) 16.49 ×10⁹/L, neutrophil percentage (Neut%) 89.1%, glucose 13.86 mmol/L, triglycerides 6.25 mmol/L. Ultrasound shows gallstones, cholecystitis, and a dilated common bile duct. Gastroscopy shows chronic superficial gastritis with erosions. Serum amylase (AMY) 2642 IU/L and urine amylase (UAMY) 2315 IU/L. Abdominal CT shows necrotizing pancreatitis, gallstones, and bilateral pleural effusion.

2. Conclusion: Obstructive jaundice
   Reasoning: Total bilirubin (TBIL) 123.1 μmol/L, direct bilirubin (DBIL) 99.0 μmol/L, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 609 U/L, aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 308 U/L; ultrasound shows gallstones, cholecystitis, and a dilated common bile duct.

3. Conclusion: Pleural effusion
   Reasoning: Abdominal CT shows necrotizing pancreatitis, gallstones, and bilateral pleural effusion.

4. Conclusion: Hepatic dysfunction
   Reasoning: Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 609 U/L and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 308 U/L
Treatment:
1. Complete tumor marker testing and contrast-enhanced abdominal MRI to clarify whether the pancreatic lesion is benign or malignant

2. Fasting and gastrointestinal decompression; fluid resuscitation and electrolyte balance; use of somatostatin (e.g., octreotide) to inhibit pancreatic secretion; anti-infective therapy, analgesia, and anti-inflammatory treatment; nutritional support; hepatoprotective therapy; percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage (PTCD) to relieve obstructive jaundice; mechanical ventilatory support; close monitoring of laboratory results
